It's a wonderful idea, but party loyalty is much more powerful today, which is a big part of our problem. Representatives have to be in open warfare, or risk primary challenges, which is the only way they can lose.

In the end, the fix is non-partisan districting focused on creating close races. That will push parties to develop candidate selection procedures designed to promote moderate candidates. Then, only then, we can have a functioning government again.

Naively, one should expect being "under 2% confidence level" about 1 year in every 50.

Yawn.

Source of protein?

I know the NYT moderators won't publish this, but I cannot resist.
We need a viable counterbalance to the governing party, it is required, along with a strong and healthy press, to keep corruption at bay.

Republicans are great at stealing other people's lunches and blaming the victims of a lack of personal responsibility.

Give them some credit for their genetic misanthropy.

The answer is to do what we did here in California. Supermajorities of Democrats in both houses. Reduce the GOP to a very small minority. It's the only thing that solved our deficit problems after divided government and Republican governors. We're on the road to surpluses now.

This isn't your father's Republican party anymore. Expanded government, surpluses to deficits, mis-manged wars, and at the end of 8-years of Bush the closest we've come to reliving the Depression.

What are the Republicans good for anyway?

People will remember this dismal time in our history. I and people like me will make sure that the country develops a long memory. The Ultra conservative faction of the republican party will fail. And once failed and their game transparent, they will not be a faction of influence. I see a lot of conservative republicans loosing elections at their next time up. I will certainly do everything I can to make this happen. I only hope that John Boehner does not win re-election

Ignorant, reckless Tea Party zealots, who hate government have control of House. They have an agenda which was made clear in the Romney-Ryan campaign, which was soundly rejected in the 2012 election. The GOP is now attempting to reverse the election without the votes to “legislate” changes they want. They are ending our form of government by high jacking and threatening to destroy our economy by defaulting on the national debt. They want a new crises every 3 or 4 months, each time demanding as a ransom items from their long list of things they want like killing Medicare and the ACA. Next crises it could be tax cuts for the rich and more austerity by balancing the budget with cuts but no new revenue.

This will become a habit and will require suspension of our Constitution. Defaulting on the debt itself would be unconstitutional. The Dems were supposed to have surrendered as the GOP is counting on their patriotism not to allow murder of their hostage. Obama has promised that there will be no default or negotiation. The GOP is now blinded. .

Obama will allow the GOP to go into default and instantly the he will order the Treasury to pay the all valid debts as they come due. The nation will see that the GOP cannot be trusted with government, and they will vote the GOP out of the House majority in a landslide in 2014. The Senate will not accept a short term debt limit raise. Time will expire and the GOP will race over the cliff to their electoral demise. RIP. You all.

@Mancuroc

I never, not even for a moment, believed it was sincere. I have no doubt that, were we to go into default, the Kochs probably have a way to profit from it.

18 USC(United States Code) 2384:

If two or more persons in any State or Territory, or in any place subject to the jurisdiction of the United States, conspire to overthrow, put down, or to destroy by force the Government of the United States, or to levy war against them, or to oppose by force the authority thereof, or by force to prevent, hinder, or delay the execution of any law of the United States, or by force to seize, take, or possess any property of the United States contrary to the authority thereof, they shall each be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than twenty years, or both.

The element of force is essential to the charge of sedition. It's not there in the present crisis.

Add to the list the impeachment of Antonin Scalia.
For he has clearly forgone judicial impartiality.

Yes, charge them wiyh sedition. The post linked to below presents the various laws on the books, and the GOP behavior in Congress is certainly a close fit. As a compromise, the President could offer a plea bargain.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/andrew-reinbach/the-gop-shutdown-is-sedit_...

Consider this solution: Rule by Law is still fundamental to the American system of government and justice. Consequently, we need to focus on the Congressional Republicans' illegal seditious acts.

House Republicans are abdicating their duties in favor of undermining the U.S. Government and the welfare of all American citizens. And they are working not with President Obama but rather, they are "owing" their allegiance to their surrogate leaders—e.g., Koch’s, Heritage, and ALEC.

Their seditious acts are premeditated, long-term, purposefully undermining the U.S. Government, intentionally harming all American citizens, and deleterious to the U.S. and global economies. Right-wing Republican sedition is seriously injuring our parent nation. And, imo, they are waging economic warfare against the U.S. for the purpose of devolving our democratic republic to a plutocratic corporatocracy aka fascist state.

This a powerful solution: charge them with sedition. Exercising existing sedition laws (Alien Registration Act, 1940) could land these right-wing Republicans in prison for 20 years.

Protect our republic, yourself, and all Americans from the politically irrational who enable the extreme minority. Free yourself from political treachery and be free of political incompetence.

Vote Republicans out of government, state and federal.

Could the Kochs just buy the Old South? They would get a country to control. It has no functioning government of its own now anyway, so no one living there would be able to tell the difference.

We would rid of them and the terrible drain they are on the rest of the country. In fact, we could actually get badly neglected things done: repair roads and bridges, create public jobs to kick-start the economy, feed the hungry, get universal health care, improve public education, and re-establish our country as reasonable, reliable and effective in the eyes of the world.

We get a sane reality-based country; they get to chase bogey-men with guns in a lawless backwater. It would be a win-win.

It is correct to call them Dixiecrats. At the rally today, led by Sen. Ted Cruz, supporters carried Confederate flags. Added to that, their absolute hatred of Pres. Obama and refusal to participate in the national government because they do not like it, reminds me of the old Democratic Senators and Congressmen from the South in the 1900s until they switched to being Republicans.
The Confederate flag is a symbol of secession and separation, as well as racism. Carrying a Confederate flag at a rally that basically has as its goal defying an African-American president, and destroying the federal government makes me think that we need a parliamentary type of government.
Perhaps if the American people were offered a choice between the Dixiecrat type party, a truly progressive party, and one or two middle-of-the-road parties, there would be much more accurate representation of where they actually stand. We also desperately need campaign finance reform; it appears that not even the Koch brothers and Heritage folks who have been financing this whole development can bring them in at this point.

Adrian O only claims to be a mathematical physicist. He is no kind of physicist at all, as he repeatedly demonstrates here on Dot Earth.

While climatology has some quantum mechanics in the atmospheric physics portion, the remainder is all macrophysics. In particular, Adrian O has demonstrated he has no understanding whatsoever of geophysics.

While he can write engagingly, that is often the mark of a charlatan. Beware.
Didn't a lot of, if not most, NYC taxi cabs run Chrysler slant sixes for years and years?

While I understand your concern about immigration from Mexico, I don't agree with it. Migration from Mexico exploded with the signing of NAFTA, which was sold as a "free trade" deal but in reality is less about freedom to trade but freedom for capital to be moved around by its owners. When capital knows no borders, its owners are always enriched at the expense of much or most of the general population. It benefited the owners of capital on both sides of the border to flood Mexico with cheap American corn. At one stroke, this undermined the livelihoods of Mexican farmers, who flooded into cities that could not support them, and then to the border. And it devalued labor in Mexico.

The pressure of immigration would be reduced by making the border less porous to capital. The "free trade" movement in general has taken jobs to the lowest-wage countries, and we have seen the result in the loss of thousands of American factories and millions of American jobs. It has widened the gap between rich and poor within nations and across national borders.

I would be pleased if longsuffering Detroit won the World Series because the people of the city can use the boost.  That does not mean I believe the average denizen of the city can afford a good seat at the game.  Pity.

Bravo, Socrates, with one caveat.  Our political-economic system guarantees the return of the privateers to guide the invisible hand-- which an observant person in this thread has pointed out is actually the man behind the curtain. As long as we leave key fossil fuels in the hands of the few, the .001 percent, the body politic will be degradated and manipulated by wealth. Also history indicates that people become complacent over the intervening decades and forget the lessons of concentrated wealth: allowing the manipulators to redo their damage. This is not a compendium of all the factors harming our society; it is mostly a warning that what is undone by graduated income taxes and progressive choices will be redone in due time by those possessing great resources, resources which should be placed in the public domain as in Norway.

"Let the greediest flee America; we don't need their cancer."

To the extent that the “greediest” = the wealthiest = the most productive then what you are advocating for our country is a brain drain. The harm would not be to fleeing “greedy” ones, but to those left behind. But our Gini coefficient would show vast improvement!

I get your drift, and I am a liberal, but you go rather wild in your specifics.

Most super rich are not "Randian pyschopaths," they are business experts, many of them Democrats and liberal.

Greed is good as well as bad, throwing money away is as destructive as greed. It is certainly not the "greatest cancer on society." That would be drug abuse, or fundamentalist religion, or violence.

Raising taxes does not regulate greed, it probably incites it.

Inviting the most wealthy (greedy to you) to "flee America" is feckless posturing. You'd have done better daring the wealthy to stand up for better wages for the middle class, many of them, including the "greedy" super billionaire Warren Buffett already do, hence the "Buffett Rule."

"The top 1 percent of Americans took home 22 percent of the nation’s income.

The top 0.1 percent, 11 percent.

Ninety-five percent of all income gains since 2009 have gone to the top 1 percent.

Recent census figures show that median income in America hasn’t budged in almost a quarter-century."
---------------------------------------

If the minimum wage had increased at the same rate since 1960 that it has for the 1%, the minimum wage would be $33 today.

And yet income tax rates for corporations and individuals have plunged in the last fifty years while sales taxes, real estate taxes and employee payroll taxes have surged.

What we have is a complete fleecing of America by obscenely wealthy Randian psychopaths that will end badly.

Greed is not good; it is destructive - it is malicious - it is evil - and it is the greatest cancer on society.

We should do our best to regulate it by raising taxes on the wealthy.

Let the greediest flee America; we don't need their cancer.

Methinks forgiveness is ever arbitrary. You don't want to run into your 'ex' around town before you've found yourself a new sweetheart. Bartman might have to lay low until the Cubs have at least had a shot at the Fall Classic.

All is forgiven by those of us sane fans.  It could have been any excited diehard fan to reach without thinking.  It's only a game but some CUBS will always need someone or some silly curse to blame for the longest losing streak--EVER.

My grandparents were "legals" (pardon the disgusting elision of "immigrants") only because the restrictive, racist immigration laws had not been passed. So, Ordinary Jen, I am taking offense.

But maybe your ancestors came a hundred years before mine so they have greater rights? Is that your point?

The problem with leftist proposals is they will only bring down the rich without helping the rest. If Mitt Romney had $190 million instead of $250 million, it's only going to modestly impact him and not help anyone else. In fact some money that would have been invested in business will not have making the economy and job growth even slower than they are so really everyone will be worse off. What we need is policies that make it easier to start businesses and hire people so more people have jobs.

Dave

What makes it easier to start businesses is customers who can afford your product or service and would like to get hold of it. Without them, all the capital in the world will not gat a sensible entrepreneur to invest. Our problem is not shortage of capital but rather shortage of affluent customers.

Mitt is speculating with his money, looking for tax shelters and undervalued companies to buy and shape up (or loot). Give his money to the bottom half of our population and it will be spent, giving businesses a solid reason to expand and invest some of the billions they are sitting on.

re Dave @ 10/14/13 9:11am

You unwittingly reveal the solution your own observation.

You start with the unproven assumption that a member of the investment class, e.g. Mr. Romney, is actually investing in businesses that create jobs and innovation. Evidence is that he's holding funds in off-shore accounts and not investing in US jobs and innovation.

Our experience as serial entrepreneurs is that money in the hands of more people is more productive than steep inequality. Consumer demand is 70% of the US economy. Business-to-business demand is a reaction to consumer demand. When we can develop new or disruptive products and show investors there is demand and a growing market we can more easily raise money.

Selling products and services to the 0.1% luxury market is very limited.

In our experience smaller investors are the true engines of growth and risk taking innovation. They're the ones with $10-100,000 in seed and angel funds that help us advance our ideas past the minimum viable product phase and into the growth phase.

At that phase we pitch the institutional investors, in our area these are known as venture capitalists and corporate strategic partners.

We've also observed that the centimillionaires we've met during this recession have been risk adverse. The decline of VC funds for long cycle medical technology is evidence. Short term financial manipulation is the flavor of the day.

Higher capital gains taxes shift the incentive to invest in higher risk returns.

It would be helpful if the author provided some practical and politically feasible suggestions to mitigate the problem, rather than simply stoke the fires of class warfare.

Starting 30 years ago, politicians somehow sold the US electorate on the idea that reducing taxes on investment income (capital gains, dividends, etc.) relative to taxes of income on work is "good for the economy". The huge disparity in taxation on investment and earned income, compounded over decades, would seem to be the most obvious cause of growing wealth inequality between the very wealthy and the middle class in the US. The Federal Reserve exacerbates this problem by artificially suppressing interest rates, which punishes ordinary savers and rewards Wall Street banks and speculators.

What does the author think? Would raising taxes on investment income reduce wealth inequality, and would it harm the economy?

And what about globalization, which seems to be the major cause of wealth inequality holding back lower wage-lower skill workers, now forced to compete against the cost of labor in Asia. This would seem to be a more vexing problem with no clear solution.

Less complaining and politicking and more analysis and proposed solutions from economists would be more informative for readers.

Yes! Let's have the Democrats negotiate for expanding Medicare to cover everyone, increasing taxes, increasing the minimum wage, banning weapons outright for everyone except peace officers and those similarly employed, and increased welfare benefits for the unemployed as well as free child care for everyone.

But no negotiations at all until the government is funded and the debt ceiling is raised.

In games theory this is a giant game of chicken- whoever gives in first is the loser, but if no one gives in both are losers and one loses more than the other. Every time the Democrats "compromise", they set up another losing game. For the Republicans tax raises, gun control, and abortion are never negotiable, even if the majority of voters want them.
Why don't we all compromise?- repeal Obamacare for Medicare for all, balance the budget like Clinton with increased taxes and welfare control, make police happy by banning assault weapons, let women decide if they want an abortion or else have taxpayers pay for unwanted children.
Ask Republicans if they would negotiate or compromise with extortionists.

So true! It is not just the money that controls the election process, but the mainstream media that brainwashes those who want their views to be reinforced. Fox News and MSNBC are essentially the same. Sure, they appeal to different demographic sides, but they are so biased in their presentation that truth and informative reporting are a very rare occurrence.

The Supreme Court has to walk a fine line in protecting the 1st Amendment versus the injection of money into politics. They have gone towards money to be sure, but it is up to voters to make the final decision.

My city, Minneapolis, has a mayoral race coming up, and we now have Ranked Choice Voting. In the past, there would be an endorsed Democrat and an endorsed Republican candidate. Now there are thirty-five candidates on the ballot. Vote for three in the order they appeal to you, and then vote again for a final winner. Much of the rest of the world does this, and they are not saddled with a two party stranglehold as we are.

The way to remove extortion from the legislative process is to arrest the extortionists, to exclude them from office, to prosecute their supporters as co-conspirators.  This is not a hypothetical problem.  The extremists are funded by individuals who hope to overthrow the democratic process at the risk of national solvency.  That is a crime, or an act of war.
But in the market transactions are mutually beneficial or they wouldn't happen. In government everything is a process of hurting one party for the benefit of another. Your comparison is meaningless.

I'm a businessman. I enter into negations as a normal part of conducting business. These negotiations take the form of either my selling or buying goods and services to or from another party. Never, ever do these interactions involve threats that can result in actual damages to either party. If threats of damages are made, then these interactions cease to be negotiations. They become acts of extortion. No one in business would voluntarily have anything to do with any party that threatens injury or damage as a part of negotiations. In fact, such dealings are against the law and are often used in racketeering.

Somehow, in the insane world of politics, extortion is considered legitimate bargaining leverage. This must not be tolerated under any circumstances.

The reverse-Dixiecrat solution is weak because these same people are also victims of the extortion they support.

The way to solve the extortion problem is to remove avenues of extortion from politics. The power of the extortionists comes from the money that controls the election process. Unfortunately, the Supreme Court is doing all it can to allow the injection of ever more money into politics from less and less diverse sources. This concentration of election funds magnifies the power of the extortionists. As an unintended consequence of treating money as speech, the Court has already corrupted politics with the ability to collapse the economy. Liberty is not intended to facilitate self-destruction.

I like your idea. Otherwise, if you are a Democrat and able to move, occupy a red district! Independents and Democrats who are sick of this mess should take over the gerrymandered areas by moving in to them.

Aside from gerrymandering, Democrats control fewer congressional districts because they dominate cities more heavily than Republicans dominate rural areas, and there is a false belief that districts must be drawn so that city residents and rural residents are in separate districts.  There is no basis for such an assumption in the Constitution.  The result is that Republicans slightly dominate a larger number of districts, while Democrats heavily dominate a smaller number of districts.  Districts need to be drawn like the slices of a pie, with a city in the center of the pie, and a piece of the center in every slice.

As a compromise, President Obama might offer not to bring criminal charges of extortion (and sedition) against the House  Republican leadership if they allow a vote on a long-term CR, and restore the sequestered funds to the budget.

Agreed, but remember that these "journalists" on TV are highly-paid entertainers who have no economic interest in seeing a stable federal government, a prosperous middle class, the saving of the safety net, etc.

Nowhere in the Constitution is there anything about shutting down the government or defunding laws that were legitimately passed using the normal Constitutional process.

And yet Republicans keep saying that these illegal and extra Constitutional tactics somehow give them the right to negotiate with the Presidend, as if this were somehow business as usual. It's not.

And everyone, including journalists who are obsessed with trying to pin blame 'on both sides' needs to call out the House Republicans on this. Why? Because, if they don't, these extra Constitutional tactics will become the norm and the country with descend into chaos.

So...every time a Republican demands negotiation...it has to be called what it is: extortion.
